Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Causes and consequences of regular spatial patterning in foundation species: theoretical development and experimental tests in an African savanna
Award.AbstractNarration:
New satellite imagery has revealed that many natural ecological systems form surprisingly uniform patterns. This project will advance our understanding about how these patterns form and how they affect resources such as water and nutrients and the abundance and distribution of plants and animals. Research will combine experimental field studies in tropical savanna in Kenya with mathematical modeling to investigate the causes and consequences of the regular pattern of large mounds formed over wide areas by soil-dwelling termites. Researchers will investigate the physical and biological mechanisms that space termite colonies, and how the mounded landscape shapes food webs and determines overall productivity and stability of the system.

This project is expected to add to the scientific basis for managing rangeland ecosystems, where self-organized patterns may be important indicators of ecological degradation and components of landscape restoration. Project data will be made freely available to the public. The project will also contribute to science education in multiple ways. A post-doctoral researcher and a number of undergraduate students, including students from underrepresented groups, will participate first-hand in the field research. Many more students will benefit from new instructional units based on the research and added to the curricula at the home universities of the researchers in the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Some species play outsized roles in shaping community structure and function, and understanding their effects is crucial for predicting system-wide dynamics. Termites are important foundation species in many ecosystems worldwide, and ecologists have documented strong effects of their mounds on many aspects of ecological systems. One apparently general phenomenon in the ecology of these species has been widely noted but little studied: the tendency of termite mounds to occur in strikingly regular, overdispersed patterns. Neither the origin (is it self-organized or imposed?) nor the broader ecological significance (when, where, and how does it actually matter?) of these patterns is understood. In this work, we conducted a large scale test of the role of spatial pattern, like that generated by termites, to alter ecological dynamics. Specifically, we fertilized areas of an African savanna either with regular spacing (as termites do) or with random placement of fertilized patches. We then followed the effects of these treatments for multiple years. We found that regular spacing increases the use of savanna areas by both large and small mammals, ranging from elephants to hares. We also find some differences in the relative abundance of some dominant plants. Somewhat surprisingly, we do not see landscape-level effects of random vs. regular spacing that are not apparently generated by mammals, suggesting that while patterning does have impacts, these are mediated by the behavioral responses of mobile animals, rather than by other possible mechanisms. This work suggests that the linkages between stationary species, such as termites, and more mobile consumers may be critical in shaping the functioning of patterned ecosystems. Our work also adds to an understanding of how and why spatial pattern matters for the conservation of healthy ecological communities.
